nodes.title: 1) Download Models
widgets_values:
You have to manually download the models you would like to use and put them into: ComfyUI/models/vibevoice/

Make a directory for each model and put all the files inside them.

VibeVoice-1.5B model (~ 5.4 GB):
https://huggingface.co/microsoft/VibeVoice-1.5B/tree/main

VibeVoice-Large model (~ 18.7 GB):
https://huggingface.co/aoi-ot/VibeVoice-Large/tree/main

VibeVoice-Large-Q-8bit model (~ 11.6 GB):
https://huggingface.co/FabioSarracino/VibeVoice-Large-Q8/tree/main

VibeVoice-Large-Q-4bit model (~ 6.6 GB):
https://huggingface.co/DevParker/VibeVoice7b-low-vram/tree/main/4bit

The narrative being sold by financial media—that the banking crisis of 2023 was a "one-off" event fixed by regulators—is a dangerous lie. We are not looking at stability; we are looking at a historic accounting concealment designed to hide the fact that hundreds of regional banks are structurally insolvent right now. In this video, I am going to break down the mechanics of the "extend and pretend" scheme that is keeping the system alive, and I will show you exactly how the bond market is mathematically guaranteed to break it. 

You need to watch this until the absolute end, because I am going to reveal the specific legal trigger—written into law—that invalidates your deposit insurance and allows the government to legally convert your cash savings into worthless bank equity during the next failure. This isn't just about banks; it's about the safety of your own capital. 

The core rot in the system is the bond trap, a mechanism that has silently hollowed out balance sheets across the country. During the stimulus years of 2020 and 2021, banks were flooded with cash and bought "risk-free" U.S. Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities when interest rates were at 0.5% to 1%. It seemed safe then, but it was a trap. 

When the Fed hiked rates to 5.5%, the value of those low-yield bonds collapsed. A bond paying 1% is toxic inventory in a 5% world unless you sell it at a massive discount. This created a situation where the paper value of a bank's assets differs wildly from reality. 

If these institutions had to sell those bonds today to pay you your deposit, the realized losses would wipe out the institution's entire capital base. This affects you directly because the institution storing your wealth may technically have a net worth of zero. 

To keep the doors open, the sector utilizes a regulatory loophole called Held-to-Maturity accounting. This rule allows a bank to value a bond at the price they bought it for, not what it is actually worth today, as long as they promise not to sell it. It is a "mark-to-fantasy" framework that lets the industry ignore hundreds of billions in losses. 

We saw this facade crumble with Silicon Valley Bank. When depositors demanded cash, the bank was forced to sell those HTM bonds. That sale crystallized the losses, and the bank collapsed in 48 hours. When you look at a bank balance sheet today, you are often looking at a fiction sanctioned by regulators to prevent a panic. 

The government's response was the Bank Term Funding Program, a temporary tourniquet that allowed banks to pledge those underwater bonds as collateral at full face value. It was effectively printing liquidity against bad assets. But that program expired in March 2024. The lifeline is cut. 

With that easy money gone, desperate banks have quietly shifted to sourcing funds from the Federal Home Loan Banks, using these advances as shadow funding to feign liquidity. This matters because it proves the stress never went away; it just moved to a different, less visible ledger. They are burning the furniture to heat the house. 

The catalyst that makes this critical right now is cash sorting. This is a silent, invisible bank run. With Treasury bills and money market funds offering 5% yields, smart depositors are moving billions out of stagnant, low-yield bank accounts. 

Every dollar that leaves the system forces banks to consume liquid reserves, stripping away the cushion that protects against insolvency. The regional banking ETF, KRE, shows this clearly: a widening gap between cash-rich mega-banks and the bleeding regional sector. This drain reduces credit for the real economy, tightening financial conditions around your business and your household. 

While the bond trap is a severe wound, the fatal blow is forming in commercial real estate (CRE). After 2008, the "Too Big to Fail" giants retreated from CRE, leaving regional banks to fill the void. Today, small and mid-sized lenders hold nearly seventy percent of total CRE loans in America. 

The exposure is often 300% or 400% of total equity capital. This is catastrophic because the asset class is facing a double shock: permanent demand destruction from remote work, and a refinancing wall at much higher rates. If these loans default, the collateral damage will vaporize the equity of hundreds of lenders instantly. 

The math allows for no escape. Vacancy rates in major cities are nearing 30%, rendering many office towers mathematically insolvent because rent can no longer cover the mortgage. Simultaneously, $2 trillion in loans originated at 3% interest are maturing between 2025 and twenty twenty seven. 

They must be refinanced at Seven or Eight percent. With income down and payments doubling, borrower default is inevitable. When a building sells at a 50% discount, the lender takes a hit that often exceeds the institution's entire capital buffer. 

The only thing stopping immediate failure is "extend and pretend." Banks are modifying loan terms for distressed borrowers, pushing out maturity dates, and pretending the asset has the same value it did in 2021. Regulators are complicit because enforcing reality would reveal half the banking system is underwater. 

This is a silent bailout where the cost is paid in prolonged economic stagnation. It creates zombie companies that cannot invest or grow, dragging down the entire economy. 

This fragile game assumes you, the depositor, remain complacent. But that is fading. Smart capital is already shorting regional banks and pulling deposits. The "first mover advantage" applies to panicked exits: those who leave first get the cash; those who wait get trapped. 

As loans mature month by month, the "extend" game hits a hard wall. Borrowers eventually run out of cash to pay even the interest. Non-performing loans are ticking higher. We are entering the decisive phase where the combined weight of empty buildings and expensive money crushes the "pretend" narrative. 

The final backstop, the FDIC, is woefully inadequate for a systemic event. The Deposit Insurance Fund holds roughly $130 billion to cover over $Seventeen trillion in deposits. That is a reserve ratio of less than 1%. 

It works for a single failure. It fails completely in a cascading regional collapse. Once the fund hits zero, the FDIC must beg Congress for a bailout, a process that will be slow and politically chaotic. You are trusting an insurance policy that is mathematically incapable of paying out if the damage spreads. 

This leads us to the ultimate risk: the bail-in. The 2010 Dodd-Frank Act established an "orderly liquidation authority." This permits regulators to recapitalize a failed bank by writing down the liabilities of unsecured creditors. 

You need to understand: legally, a depositor is an unsecured creditor. Funds over the $250,000 limit can be forcibly converted into equity in the failed bank. This isn't theory; it happened in Cyprus and it is the global model. While they saved SVB depositors, that was a choice, not a law. Next time, they might not choose you. 

The result is a two-tier system. Global Systemically Important Banks have an implicit government guarantee. The 4,000 regional banks become death traps. This forces a massive consolidation of deposits to the mega-banks. 

It is a slow-motion nationalization of the sector. This centralization paves the road for Central Bank Digital Currency as the only "safe" public option. The crisis isn't over. It is evolving into a phase where the losses embedded in the system are transferred from the bank's balance sheet... to yours.

nodes.title: 2) Download Tokenizer
widgets_values:
You have to manually download the Qwen2.5 Tokenizer files and put them into: ComfyUI/models/vibevoice/tokenizer/

https://huggingface.co/Qwen/Qwen2.5-1.5B/tree/main

Required files: tokenizer_config.json, vocab.json, merges.txt, tokenizer.json (~11MB)

Put the files directly inside tokenizer directory without make another directory inside.

nodes.title: Load Text From File
widgets_values: Use Load Text From File if you want to use a .txt file instead of text-area. You can load .txt files from ComfyUI/input, ComfyUI/output or ComfyUI/temp directories.

nodes.title: Voice Speed Factor
widgets_values: The voice speed factor influences the original source audio to attempt to achieve a slower or faster final speech. 1.0 is the normal speed. It is recommended not to exceed values ​​between 0.95 and 1.05. The effect is best when you provide a sample audio of at least 20 seconds.
